author: By Michael Romano
title: How Biden Can Tackle Mass Incarceration
description: A little-used law could empower prison officials to recommend to judges that they release incarcerated people who have demonstrated rehabilitation.
content: As a candidate, Joe Biden said he would substantially reduce the federal prison population as president. Last week he commuted the sentences of 11 people who he said were serving unjustifiably harsh prison terms for drug offenses and also pardoned people convicted of certain marijuana charges. Still, the number of people in federal prison has grown during the Biden administration.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Thomas L. Friedman
title: What Is Happening to Our World?
description: The Israel-Hamas war was not as inevitable as you might think.
content: I’ve been The Times’s foreign affairs columnist since 1995, and one of the most enduring lessons I’ve learned is that there are good seasons and bad seasons in this business, which are defined by the big choices made by the biggest players.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Dan Barry
title: Where You Can Still Glimpse the Glory of a Vanished Grand Hotel
description: A mile north of where the Hotel Pennsylvania once stood, a shimmering piece of its history can still be seen through a shop window.
content: An absence rises from the Manhattan pavement, a Seventh Avenue nothingness soaring 22 stories into the Midtown sky. There is vacancy now where the Hotel Pennsylvania once stood.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Tim McKeough
title: What’s Better Than a Tiny Island Cabin? Two, Side by Side.
description: For years, the antique cottage off the coast of Washington had served her well. But with grandchildren on the way, she needed a little extra space.
content: Some tiny homes seem so ideal that it’s tempting to avoid changing them, even when life demands otherwise. That’s how Pam Austin felt when her family began outgrowing the 450-square-foot log cabin she owns on Guemes Island, off the coast of Washington.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Amanda Holpuch
title: Exactly How We Figured Out Just How Rich the McCallister Family Was
description: To get to the bottom of the family’s wealth in ‘Home Alone,’ a reporter had to watch the 1990 film — for the first time.
content: In late November, when one of my editors, Erin McCann, suggested I look into how rich the McCallister family was in “Home Alone,” I had to make a confession: I had never seen the movie.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Benjamin Mullin
title: Inside the News Industry’s Uneasy Negotiations With OpenAI
description: Several major publishers have been in talks to license content to the creator of ChatGPT, but agreement on the price and terms has been elusive.
content: For months, some of the biggest players in the U.S. media industry have been in confidential talks with OpenAI on a tricky issue: the price and terms of licensing their content to the artificial intelligence company.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Maya Phillips
title: ‘Doctor Who’ Welcomed Its 15th Doctor. Here’s How He Stacks Up.
description: As Ncuti Gatwa makes his proper debut, we take a look back at the recent history of those to inhabit the TARDIS.
content: With most TV shows, a major casting change is a dreaded event. But for fans of the long-running British series “Doctor Who,” big casting changes are expected, even anticipated. With the show’s latest Christmas episode, which premiered Monday on Disney+, we got acquainted with the newest Doctor, played by Ncuti Gatwa (“Sex Education”) — the 15th Doctor and the first Black, openly queer one in series history.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Penelope Green
title: Mike Nussbaum, Celebrated Chicago Theater Actor, Dies at 99
description: He appeared memorably in “American Buffalo” and in the Pulitzer Prize-winning play “Glengarry Glen Ross.” But he gave up a career on Broadway for one in Chicago.
content: Mike Nussbaum, an actor  known as the dean of Chicago theater who found success during his early association with the Chicago-born playwright David Mamet, died on Dec. 23 at his home in Chicago. He was 99.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Deb Amlen
title: Raspberry Relative
description: Happy Robyn Weintraub Friday! Please celebrate responsibly.
content: Jump to: Tricky Clues
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Tammy LaGorce
title: Hitting a Home Run on Their First Date, With the Help of a Furry Friend
description: Once Margaret Kretzmer got past the photo of Patrick Pennel on a flamingo float on his dating profile, the pair bonded over their mutual love for baseball.
content: On July 18, 2021, the day Patrick Alan Pennel was supposed to meet Margaret Ann Kretzmer for a first date, he canceled to spend time with someone else he was getting to know. When Ms. Kretzmer offered to meet him the following day instead, he said OK but brought the other girl along.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Heather Knight and Sergio Olmos
title: Giant Waves Close Out California’s Remarkable Year of Weather Phenomena
description: Along the coast, residents on Thursday saw waves that topped 30 feet and flooded beachfront neighborhoods in some areas.
content: Giant waves pounded the coast of California on Thursday, causing big headaches, closing beaches and toppling some people who watched the unusual waterfront show.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Chris Buckley
title: Hong Kong Activist Flees to Britain, Citing Police Pressure
description: The activist, Tony Chung, was imprisoned after advocating for the territory’s independence. Even after his release, he said, his situation remained oppressive.
content: A political activist in Hong Kong previously imprisoned under its sweeping national security law said he had fled to Britain and would apply for asylum there, becoming the second high-profile dissident this month to announce going into exile from the territory.
source.name: The New York Times

title: Quotation of the Day: Despite War, Foreigners Who Made Ukraine Home Decide to Stay Put
description: Quotation of the Day for Friday, December 29, 2023.
content: “I’m not stuck in Ukraine. I don’t want to leave.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Kate Manne
title: What if ‘Food Noise’ Is Just … Hunger?
description: One of the most basic of human drives is being reframed as a problem to be solved. We should resist.
content: Before 2022, there was barely a whisper about it. Now the concept of “food noise” is ubiquitous on social media; a quick TikTok search, for instance, finds that videos related to “food noise explained” attracted 1.8 billion views as of this summer. Coined to name the experience of thinking about food, longing for food, planning our next meal and so on, “food noise” is a slick rebrand of some of the most basic human drives: hunger, appetite, craving. But now these are being framed as bugs, rather than features. We should resist this reframing.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Alix Wall
title: On the Wedding Day, Taking the Plunge (Quite Literally)
description: Hayley Hitchcock met Brandon Brown on Hinge while waiting out the Covid-19 pandemic with her parents in Bozeman, Mont. Before their ceremony, Mr. Brown took an icy dive in the Gallatin River.
content: In April 2020, Hayley Anne Hitchcock left Seattle to move in with her parents and sister in her native Bozeman, Mont., during the Covid 19 pandemic. She didn’t plan on staying long; when things normalized, she intended to move to Denver.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Aaron Boxerman, Isabel Kershner and Thomas Fuller
title: Israel Expresses Regret for ‘Unintended Harm’ to Civilians in Gaza Airstrike
description: The Israeli military said it was “working to draw lessons” from an attack in central Gaza that was reported to have killed dozens of people.
content: The Israeli military said on Thursday that it had caused “unintended harm” to “uninvolved civilians” in two strikes this week on a densely packed Gaza Strip neighborhood, where, the local health authorities said, dozens were killed.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Megan Specia
title: In a British Town, a New Way of Caring for Older People Is Bringing Hope
description: An “integrated care center” brings doctors, physiotherapists, social workers and pharmacists under one roof. It won’t solve Britain’s underlying social care crisis — but it could help.
content: For 12 years after her husband died, Norma Fitzgerald tried to maintain her independence, living alone in an apartment on the outskirts of Hull, in northern England, despite her mobility worsening as she reached her mid-80s.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jenna Russell, Alicia Anstead and Sydney Cromwell
title: In Maine, Questions Over Decision to Push Trump Off the Ballot
description: Some voters were alarmed at the state’s decision to disqualify former President Donald J. Trump. But others applauded it. “I like that Maine took a stand,” said one.
content: A day after Maine became the second state to bar former President Donald J. Trump from its primary ballot, citing his role in the Jan. 6 attack on the U.S. Capitol, voters who found themselves thrust into a national spotlight on Friday voiced reactions as varied and complex as the legal questions threaded through the decision itself.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Constant Méheut and Daria Mitiuk
title: Russia Pounds Ukrainian Cities in One of the Largest Air Attacks of the War
description: The missile and drone attacks killed at least 30 people and damaged critical industrial and military infrastructure, part of a wintertime campaign that Ukraine had been dreading.
content: Russia targeted Ukrainian cities with more than 150 missiles and drones on Friday morning, in what Ukrainian officials said was one of the largest air assaults of the war. At least 30 people were killed, and more than 160 were wounded, according to the Ukrainian government, and critical infrastructure was damaged.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Clyde McGrady
title: AMC Theaters Apologizes to Civil Rights Leader Removed From Movie Theater
description: The Rev. William J. Barber II was trying to watch “The Color Purple” with his mother when theater staff told him he could not use a chair he needs to help manage a painful condition.
content: AMC Theaters has apologized to the Rev. William J. Barber II, a civil rights leader, after he was escorted from a Greenville, N.C., theater after employees refused to allow him to use a chair he needs to manage a painful medical condition, he said.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Lauren Christensen
title: The ‘Fantasy Dreamscapes’ of Basil Pao
description: “Carnival of Dreams” collects surrealist photo collages by the Hong Kong artist who once designed graphics for “Monty Python.”
content: Like his Surrealist forebear René Magritte, Basil Pao began his artistic career as a graphic designer, creating album and book covers and Monty Python posters in 1970s New York. In the decades since, he’s harnessed his multimedia talents into a solo oeuvre of visually and conceptually surprising photographs and collages: of people, animals, historical sites and landscapes around the world.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By The New York Times Books Staff
title: 18 New Books Coming in January
description: A look at the Trump-DeSantis rivalry, a witty tribute to “Murder on the Orient Express,” a memoir of open marriage and an epic Swedish novel in verse, among others.
content: Burns’s second novel introduces the Josephs, a roofing family in Mercury, Pa., who — along with a young woman in search of her own place in the world — find themselves at an inflection point forged by long-ago choices.
source.name: The New York Times

title: Corrections: Dec. 29, 2023
description: Corrections that appeared in print on Friday, Dec. 29, 2023.
content: An article on Thursday about the unveiling of a statue of the artist Shakira in Barranquilla, Colombia, misstated the relationship between Shakira and Gerard Piqué. While they were partners, they were never married.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Bernhard Warner
title: What Could Go Right (and Wrong) in the Markets Next Year
description: Wall Street’s forecasts mostly missed this year’s bull market rally. Here’s what strategists are saying about 2024.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Michael Barbaro, Rob Szypko, Carlos Prieto, Will Reid, Mooj Zadie, Lexie Diao, Michael Benoist, Dan Powell, Elisheba Ittoop, Diane Wong and Chris Wood
title: Baseball’s Plan To Save Itself From Boredom: An Update
description: A look at the sport’s home run problem and the big changes this season.
content: This week, The Daily is revisiting some of our favorite episodes of the year and checking in on what has happened in the time since they first ran.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Benjamin Weiser and Jonah E. Bromwich
title: Michael Cohen Used Artificial Intelligence in Feeding Lawyer Bogus Cases
description: Donald Trump’s former fixer had sought an early end to court supervision after his 2018 campaign finance conviction. He enlisted the help of Google Bard.
content: Michael D. Cohen, the onetime fixer for former President Donald J. Trump, mistakenly gave his lawyer bogus legal citations concocted by the artificial intelligence program Google Bard, he said in court papers unsealed on Friday.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Bryant Rousseau
title: The Year in People: Our 12 Favorite Saturday Profiles of 2023
description: From a Nobel Peace Prize winner, to a mayor hunted by the Russians, to a poet whose muses are cats, our profiles featured people shaping the world around them, often under the radar.
content: A teenager jailed in Egypt, determined to bear witness to the abuses he suffered during years of detention. A proponent of peace in Colombia, shadowed by death threats. A father in India, fighting his own patriarchal impulses to give his two daughters a better life.
source.name: The New York Times

title: Does Israel Need ‘Tough Love’ From the U.S.?
description: Readers react to a column by Thomas L. Friedman and a news story. Also: Dangerous child labor; windowless bedrooms; healing power of knitting.
content: To the Editor:
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Mike Ives
title: 25-Foot Waves and Widespread Rain: West Coast Hit by More Storms
description: Millions of people in coastal areas of California and Oregon were under high surf warnings overnight. Rain and high winds are in the forecast.
content: Rain, coastal flooding and waves as tall as 25 feet were expected along parts of the West Coast through the weekend, after giant waves pummeled the California shoreline and prompted some evacuation warnings.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Vivian Marino
title: Townhouses Took Off in December, and Neighbors Filed a Rare Joint Listing
description: Two townhouses in the West Village, one owned by the producer Scott Rudin, are listed together at $37.5 million. They could be combined into a 40-foot-wide mansion.
content: Manhattan townhouses took center stage in December, with several big sales and a prominent listing.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Amy Harmon
title: Ohio Governor Blocks Bill Banning Transition Care for Minors
description: Gov. Mike DeWine’s veto of the bill, which also prohibited transgender girls and women from sports teams that correspond with their gender identity, is a rare move by a Republican governor.
content: Mike DeWine, the Republican governor of Ohio, vetoed a bill on Friday that would have barred transgender minors from receiving puberty blockers, hormone therapy and surgeries, a rare rejection in what has been a concerted effort by the Republican Party to mobilize cultural conservatives around transgender issues for the 2024 primaries.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jeffery C. Mays and Emma G. Fitzsimmons
title: How’s Mayor Adams Doing? Don’t Ask, Many New Yorkers Say.
description: Halfway through his term, Mr. Adams is fighting to overcome low poll numbers and questions about his management as he faces a federal corruption investigation.
content: Four days before Christmas, Mayor Eric Adams of New York gathered his top aides on the stairs of City Hall’s rotunda for an end-of-year message.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Christopher Kuo
title: Jermaine Jackson Is Accused of Sexual Assault in Lawsuit
description: In a complaint filed Wednesday in Los Angeles, Rita Barrett says the musician raped her at her home in 1988. Mr. Jackson has not yet responded.
content: Jermaine Jackson, one of Michael Jackson’s older brothers and a founding member of the Jackson 5, was accused of sexual assault in a civil suit filed Wednesday in California.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Esther Zuckerman
title: ‘The Curse’ Season 1, Episode 8 Recap: Exhausting
description: In a series full of painful-to-watch interactions, this week’s episode might be the most excruciating yet.
content: This week’s episode of “The Curse” is about friendship. Or maybe, more accurately, it’s about the concept of friendship and the trouble our protagonists seem to have with grasping it. Asher and Whitney call people “friends,” but that’s just empty language to them. They have no true sense of what it means to be a friend to someone else.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Chris Buckley
title: China Appoints Naval Commander as Defense Minister
description: The promotion of Adm. Dong Jun may calm uncertainty after the unexplained disappearance of the previous minister, Gen. Li Shangfu.
content: China on Friday appointed a naval commander with experience in the South China Sea as its minister of defense, filling a monthslong vacancy created by the unexplained disappearance of the previous minister, who appeared to have fallen in an investigation into possible corruption or other misdeeds.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Adam Liptak
title: How the Supreme Court May Rule on Trump’s Presidential Run
description: The legal issues are novel and tangled, experts said, and the justices may be wary of knocking a leading presidential candidate off the ballot.
content: The Supreme Court, battered by ethics scandals, a dip in public confidence and questions about its legitimacy, may soon have to confront a case as consequential and bruising as Bush v. Gore, the 2000 decision that handed the presidency to George W. Bush.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Angelo Fichera
title: Biden’s Christian ‘Persecution’? We Assess Trump’s Recent Claims.
description: Former President Donald J. Trump has repeatedly accused the Biden administration of criminalizing Christians, and Catholics in particular, for their faith. Here are the facts.
content: Former President Donald J. Trump has repeatedly tried to appeal to Christian voters in recent weeks by accusing the Biden administration of criminalizing Americans for their faith.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Elyssa Dudley, Larissa Anderson and Daniel Ramirez
title: The Best TV Shows That Ended This Year
description: All good things must come to an end.
content: Our television critic Margaret Lyons says goodbye to three beloved shows that ended in 2023.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Steve Inskeep
title: What Nikki Haley Didn’t Say
description: Questions about the Civil War seemed to trip up the Republican candidate for president.
content: Nikki Haley drew criticism this week for what she didn’t say. As she campaigned in New Hampshire for the Republican presidential nomination, a person asked her to name the cause of the Civil War.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Rosalie R. Radomsky
title: A Romance Furthered by After-Hours Strolls Through the Met
description: Pavol Roskovensky, who once worked at the museum, deepened his relationship with Claire Anderson-Wheeler while giving her special tours.
content: Pavol Roskovensky eagerly gave Claire Anderson-Wheeler the inside scoop on the Temple of Dendur, pointing out centuries-old graffiti, like “Leonardo 1820,” on its gate and walls as they strolled through the Metropolitan Museum of Art after-hours. She also got an intimate look at her favorite Monet, Bonnard and Van Gogh paintings in the Impressionist collection.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By New York Times Games
title: Spelling Bee Forum
description: Feeling stuck on today’s puzzle? We can help.
content: Hi busy bees! Welcome to today’s Spelling Bee forum. There are a number of terms that appear in both this article and other online discussions of the Spelling Bee; a glossary of those terms compiled by Monicat, a Times reader, can be found below.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Alex Williams
title: Jim Ladd, Free-Form Radio Trailblazer, Is Dead at 75
description: An institution of the airwaves in Los Angeles and beyond, he capitalized on the freedom the FM band offered in the 1970s to blaze his own path.
content: Jim Ladd, a maverick Los Angeles disc jockey who helped pioneer free-form FM radio in the 1970s, and who went on to become a rock institution and an inspiration for Tom Petty’s song “The Last DJ,” died on Dec. 17 at his home near Sacramento, Calif. He was 75.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Bhadra Sharma and John Yoon
title: Pilot Pulled the Wrong Levers in Nepal Crash That Killed 72, Investigators Find
description: One pilot changed the propeller angle instead of that of the wing flaps while trying to land a Yeti Airlines plane in January, a report said.
content: A plane crash that killed dozens of people in Nepal in January was caused by a pilot who pulled the incorrect levers while trying to land, the country’s investigators said Thursday.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Cade Metz
title: Audiobook of the Week: How to ‘Contain’ the Threat of A.I.?
description: In “The Coming Wave,” the British social activist turned tech entrepreneur Mustafa Suleyman explores the existential risks of our new digital age.
content: Near the end of “The Coming Wave,” his sweeping look at the future of artificial intelligence and other transformative technologies, Mustafa Suleyman acknowledges the whiplash that listeners must feel as he guides them through this strange new territory — and makes no apologies for it. “If this book feels contradictory in its attitude toward technology, part positive and part foreboding,” he says, “that’s because such a contradictory view is the most honest assessment of where we are.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Natasha Frost
title: Friday Briefing
description: Hamas’s campaign of sexual violence.
content: A two-month investigation by The Times, including interviews with more than 150 people, uncovered painful new details about the attacks by Hamas on Oct. 7, established a pattern of gender-based sexual violence and identified at least seven locations where Israeli women and girls appeared to have been sexually assaulted or mutilated.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Chris Cameron
title: Trump Rivals Criticize Maine Decision in His Defense
description: Ron DeSantis and Vivek Ramaswamy were quick to take swipes at the secretary of state’s ballot decision, while the state’s congressional delegation appeared split on the matter.
content: Former President Donald J. Trump’s rivals in the Republican race for president again lined up in his defense on Thursday after Maine barred him from its primary election ballot, the second state to do so.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Alex Traub
title: Her Sculptures Were Ignored for 33 Years. Then She Got a New Roommate.
description: Hanna Eshel did not succeed in the New York art world. Her only reliable exhibit space was her own loft. But a musician in search of a home changed that.
content: Hanna Eshel waited more than 40 years for a stroke of luck in her art career.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Danial Adkison
title: Scarlet Sweaters and Scotch Tape: Readers Share Their Travel Hacks
description: A few months ago, we asked you for your favorite travel tips. Here are some standouts that could help make everyone’s next trip a bit better.
content: The next time you’re on a plane, if the person next to you doesn’t seem to own anything that isn’t bright red, it might be Celia Paerels. Kindle case, sweater, sunglasses, headphones, charging cord, everything in shocking scarlet: It’s how she avoids leaving anything behind in the seat or the seat pocket.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jan Ransom, Amy Julia Harris and José A. Alvarado Jr
title: How Rikers Island Became New York’s Largest Mental Institution
description: A seemingly endless rotation between state forensic hospitals and city jails has meant that some mentally ill detainees stay in the system for years without ever standing trial.
content: One night in fall 2015, an 18-year-old woman was standing on a subway platform in the Bronx when a homeless man named James Dolo came up from behind and used both hands to push her onto the tracks, the police said, injuring her.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ginia Bellafante
title: Six New Yorkers Who Made the City a Better, Cooler, Fairer Place in 2023
description: In a year that made many of us want to give up, these unsung activists found a way to help others.
content: Year-end lists are entirely subjective, often maddening and frequently inexplicable. So let’s explain the logic behind this one: It aims to highlight New Yorkers who, though you were probably not aware of them, have come at some of the city’s biggest challenges from unexpected angles. You’re likely to have your own ideas, and I would love to hear about them in the Comments.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Siobhan Roberts
title: Need a Home for 80,000 Puzzles? Try an Italian Castle.
description: Earlier this year, George and Roxanne Miller relocated the world’s largest collection of mechanical puzzles from their home in Florida. But first they took a road trip.
content: Meet the Millers, George and Roxanne, proprietors of the world’s largest collection of mechanical puzzles: physical objects that a puzzler holds and manipulates while seeking a solution. In total, the Miller collection — an accumulation of collections, and collections of collections — amounts to more than 80,000 puzzles. It comprises some five thousand Rubik’s Cubes, including a 2-by-2-by-2 rendering of Darth Vader’s head. And there are more than 7,000 wooden burr puzzles, such as the interlocking, polyhedral creations by Stewart Coffin, a Massachusetts puzzle maker; they evoke a hybrid of a pine cone and a snowflake and are Mr. Miller’s favorites. Mrs. Miller is fond of their 140 brass, bronze and gold puzzle sculptures by the Spanish artist Miguel Berrocal; Goliath, a male torso in 79 pieces, is “a puzzle that all puzzlers lust after,” she said.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Helene Stapinski
title: Climate Museum Pops Up in SoHo, Capital of Buying Stuff
description: After four tries, its founder hopes patrons support a permanent home. “We burn through a lot of carbon having to move every six months,” she said.
content: On a 60-degree Saturday in December — no longer unseasonably warm in Manhattan by today’s climate standards — hordes of holiday shoppers flooded the luxury shopping center that is SoHo. On a street lined with high-end stores like Chanel and Canada Goose stood a young woman handing out free coffee to lure people into a storefront that has nothing — or maybe everything — to do with conspicuous consumption.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Chris Miller and Jordan Schneider
title: How to Stop Our High-Tech Equipment From Arming Russia and China
description: The Biden administration needs to enforce its effort to keep highly strategic technology from winding up in Russia and China.
content: The U.S. government’s efforts to stop Russia and China from using American equipment to boost their defense sectors have resulted in tough rules — but leaky enforcement. As a result, American-made tools keep turning up in Russian missile factories and in Huawei’s supply chain. With war in Europe and China threatening its neighbors, that’s just not good enough.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ceylan Yeginsu
title: They Sold Everything to Go on a 3-Year Cruise. How It All Unraveled.
description: The Life at Sea cruise was supposed to be the ultimate bucket-list experience: 382 port calls worldwide over 1,095 days. The only thing missing was a trip-worthy ship.
content: Kara and Joe Youssef sold their two apartments, withdrew their life savings, gave up most of their belongings and, in late October, set out for Istanbul for the trip of a lifetime: a three-year cruise around the world, scheduled to depart Nov. 1.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jon Pareles
title: Hey, Pop Stars: Think Twice Before Messing With the Past
description: There’s good financial reason to revisit old or released material — and new technology is making it easier — but most trips back in 2023 resulted in diminishing returns.
content: Who says hindsight is 20/20?
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Robert Daniels
title: Five Action Movies to Stream Now
description: This month’s picks include tales of Southern crime, a slick Japanese remake, a hunt for hidden treasure and more.
content: I never knew I needed to hear Pierce Brosnan with a Southern accent until Phillip Noyce’s “Fast Charlie.” The former Bond plays the titular “problem solver,” as he calls himself, cooler than a summer breeze. A turf war between his boss, Stan (James Caan in one of his final film roles) and a New Orleans gangster named Beggar (Gbenga Akinnagbe) results in the apparent murder of Stan and his entire crew, pushing Charlie to seek vengeance before Beggar finds him, too. Charlie’s predicament also envelops his lover, Marcie (Morena Baccarin), a sharp-talking taxidermist.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Sopan Deb
title: This Body Butter at Sephora Doesn’t Really Attract Spiders, Right?
description: A Sol de Janeiro moisturizer has garnered attention after reviews claimed it attracted Wolf spiders. Experts say it’s likelier that the season is leading to more human-spider interactions.
content: I was just thinking about what I wanted for my birthday, which is coming soon. And the one thing I’m missing in life is a lotion that makes my skin feel super moisturized and attracts Wolf spiders.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By New York Times Games
title: The Connections Companion
description: In case you need some puzzle help.
content: Good morning, dear connectors. Welcome to today’s Connections forum, where you can give and receive puzzle — and emotional — support.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ernesto Londoño
title: Maine Law ‘Required That I Act’ to Disqualify Trump, Secretary of State Says
description: Barring former President Donald J. Trump from the primary ballot was a hard but necessary call, Shenna Bellows said in an interview.
content: Before she decided to bar former President Donald J. Trump from Maine’s primary ballot, Shenna Bellows, the secretary of state, was not known for courting controversy.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jancee Dunn
title: The New Year’s Resolutions That Changed Your Lives
description: We asked about the goals and intentions you set for yourselves. Here are some of our favorites.
content: I used to make New Year’s resolutions that unraveled by the end of January — like my big plan to get my finances in order at the start of 2019 (and 2020, and 2021). But last year, after several of my friends lost parents, I made a resolution that I’ve been able to keep.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Anushka Patil and Thomas Fuller
title: Displaced Gazans in the South Facing Dangers They Had Sought to Escape
description: Many residents feel that no place is safe after an airstrike in an area of southern Gaza where Israel had ordered people to seek shelter.
content: The Israeli military warned on Friday that it was stepping up operations in the southern Gaza Strip, where hundreds of thousands of people had fled to safety, while hospital officials said Israel bombed an area in the south where it had ordered civilians to seek shelter.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ann Carrns
title: Now May Be the Time to Lock In High Interest Rates on Your Savings
description: Rates on C.D.s are the highest they’ve been in years. But the Fed is signaling that it may cut its borrowing costs next year, and C.D. rates could follow.
content: If you want to lock in generous rates on your cash savings for the next year or so, now may be the time to do it.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Richard Sandomir
title: Gerry Holzman, Master Carver of a New York Merry-Go-Round, Dies at 90
description: He conceived and worked for 20 years — with about 1,000 volunteers — on the Empire State Carousel, featuring more than 20 handmade wooden riding animals native to New York.
content: Gerry Holzman, a master woodcarver who conceived, and toiled for 20 years to build, a merry-go-round that celebrated New York State with riding animals like a beaver, a cow and a pig, as well as portrait panels of citizens like Susan B. Anthony, Grandma Moses and Theodore Roosevelt, died on Dec. 8 at his home in Brunswick, Maine. He was 90.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Roni Caryn Rabin
title: Israeli Military Releases New Details on Killing of 3 Hostages
description: In the latest disclosure on the shooting by Israeli soldiers of three hostages, the military said 15 minutes elapsed between the killing of the first two and the third.
content: New details released by the Israeli military about the accidental killing of three Israeli hostages in Gaza City include that there was a gap of 15 minutes between the fatal shootings of the first two hostages and the third and that a commander had urged the third hostage to come out of hiding just before he was fatally shot.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Anna Grace Lee
title: Married in the Spotlight on a Broadway Stage
description: When Corey Mach and Marco D’Angelo first met, Mr. D’Angelo had only ever seen three musicals, the tip of the theatrical iceberg. Then he fell in love with a Broadway actor.
content: When Corey Joseph Mach and Salvatore Marco D’Angelo first met, they already knew each other.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Anthony Tommasini
title: A Pilgrimage to Verdi-land
description: A critic whose love of the operas of Giuseppe Verdi goes back nearly 60 years traveled to northern Italy to visit the places that shaped the man and his music.
content: I was 15 when I went to my first Verdi opera, “Il Trovatore,” at the Met, the old Met, in 1964. I could barely figure out what was going on but didn’t care. Leontyne Price sang Leonora, and I was in awe of her plush, beautiful voice. The singing, the chorus, the orchestra, the emotional drama, the music with its mixture of soaring melody, intensity and structure (though I couldn’t have expressed this back then) all hooked me. Two months later I was back at the Met for Verdi’s “Otello” starring, no less, Renata Tebaldi as Desdemona. I still remember the poignant warmth and uncanny bloom of her voice as she sang the sighing refrain of “salce, salce” in the “Willow Song.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Kurt Lash
title: Trump Should Not Be Disqualified by an Ambiguous Clause
description: The court should limit the clause to its historically verifiable meaning and scope and let the people make their own decisions about our next president.
content: Challenges to disqualify Donald Trump from the office of president under Section 3 of the 14th Amendment are popping up all over the country. On Thursday the secretary of state of Maine ruled that Mr. Trump would be ineligible for the state’s primary ballot, a decision that can be appealed to the state’s Supreme Court. On Wednesday the Michigan Supreme Court ruled narrowly that the state will allow Mr. Trump to stay on the primary ballot but left open a potential future challenge to his inclusion on a general-election ballot.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Dacia Fusaro
title: The Secret Sorrow of Hotel Rooms
description: After losing my husband, I just wanted to feel alive. Then I wanted more.
content: My exact words to him on our first date were: “I’m not looking to integrate anyone into my life. I’m looking to escape my life.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Traci Carl
title: South Africa accuses Israel of genocide in a U.N. court.
description: Israel’s Foreign Ministry said the filing was a “despicable and contemptuous exploitation of the court.”
content: South Africa accused Israel of genocide on Friday in the International Court of Justice and asked the U.N. court to order a halt to fighting in the embattled Gaza Strip, saying that Israel was trying to “destroy Palestinians in Gaza.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Victor Mather
title: Bobby Rivers, Amiable and Multifaceted Television Host, Dies at 70
description: After getting his start as an entertainment reporter and film critic, he went on to host a show on the Food Network and establish a presence in the blogosphere.
content: Bobby Rivers, an affable and playful television host, entertainment reporter and film critic, died on Tuesday in Minneapolis. He was 70.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Hurubie Meko
title: N.Y.C. Officials Reassure Revelers Ahead of New Year’s Eve Festivities
description: Amid near-daily protests in the city, officials said there were “no specific credible threats” related to the annual ball drop in Times Square.
content: New York officials on Friday tried to reassure people planning to take in Times Square on New Year’s Eve that there were “no specific credible threats” against Sunday’s festivities.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Claire Fahy and Chelsia Rose Marcius
title: Man Charged in Grand Central Stabbings Slashed Inmate, Officials Say
description: Steven Hutcherson, who was charged in the stabbings of two teenage sisters on Christmas Day, slashed a detainee on Rikers Island three days later, the authorities said.
content: A Bronx man facing attempted murder charges after he stabbed two girls at Grand Central Terminal on Christmas Day slashed a fellow Rikers Island detainee in the head and face on Thursday, seriously injuring him, according to Correction Department officials.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By the staff of The Morning
title: Overlooked Stories of 2023
description: A selection of stories that Times editors thought deserved more readers.
content: Before the internet, there was no way for New York Times editors to know how many people had read an article. Stories that ran on the front page of the newspaper presumably were better read than ones on Page 36, but nobody could be sure.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Claire Moses
title: What Your Favorite Streaming Services Will Cost You in 2024
description: Amazon will start showing ads to some Prime Video subscribers who pay less. They’re not alone.
content: If you were planning on watching the final season of “Jack Ryan” or eight seasons of “House” without commercials on Amazon Prime next year, get ready to dig a little deeper into your pockets.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Alyson Krueger
title: 10, 9, 8, 7 … or Even 6 p.m.: Count Down for the New Year Any Time You Like
description: It’s probably midnight somewhere, right?
content: To welcome 2024 the Children’s Museum of Manhattan is hosting a big New Year’s Eve party, where a D.J. will be spinning family-friendly tunes and attendees will make their own party hats. But the main event will be a countdown. The crowd, consisting of parents and their children, will count down “10, nine, eight, seven, six, five, four, three, two, one” before throwing confetti into the air, shaking noisemakers and watching a ball, made of mylar and decorated with sparkles, descend from the ceiling.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ivan Nechepurenko
title: Russia Sends Navalny Associate to Prison for ‘Extremism’
description: The nine-year sentence reflects how the Kremlin continues to crack down on Aleksei A. Navalny’s political movement years after his organization was banned.
content: A court in Siberia on Friday sentenced an ally of the jailed Russian opposition leader Aleksei A. Navalny to nine years in a penal colony for running an “extremist organization,” according to her legal team. The sentence signals the Kremlin’s willingness to continue cracking down on members of Mr. Navalny’s political group years after it was banned in Russia.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Nicholas Bogel-Burroughs and Mitch Smith
title: What to Know About the Efforts to Remove Trump From the 2024 Ballot
description: There are lawsuits pending in more than a dozen states seeking to have Donald J. Trump disqualified from appearing on primary ballots.
content: The campaign to have former President Donald J. Trump removed from the ballot over his efforts to remain in power after the 2020 election has kicked into high gear, with decisions in two states, Maine and Colorado, barring him from the primary ballots.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Azmat Khan and Eric Schmitt
title: Pentagon’s New Plans to Reduce Civilian Deaths Leave Questions Over Israel
description: The document codifies procedures for U.S. combat but does not address operations the United States supports through military aid alone.
content: The Pentagon has established new procedures for preventing and responding to civilian harm during U.S. combat operations, following up on a pledge by Defense Secretary Lloyd J. Austin III to overhaul the system.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Alexandra Stevenson
title: Hong Kong Stocks Plunge to Losses for 4th Straight Year
description: Investors worried about China’s economy shunned Hong Kong’s stock market, once one of the biggest and most important in the world.
content: This summer, when Hong Kong’s stock market rout seemed to have no end in sight, the city’s financial chief, Paul Chan, jumped into action, creating a task force to inject confidence into a market that was being pummeled by global investors wary of China.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Tim Arango and Campbell Robertson
title: After Rise in Murders During the Pandemic, a Sharp Decline in 2023
description: The country is on track for a record drop in homicides, and many other categories of crime are also in decline, according to the F.B.I.
content: Detroit is on track to record the fewest murders since the 1960s. In Philadelphia, where there were more murders in 2021 than in any year on record, the number of homicides this year has fallen more than 20 percent from last year. And in Los Angeles, the number of shooting victims this year is down more than 200 from two years ago.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Rebecca Thomas
title: A Year of Girls Spilling Their Guts
description: From the pop supernova Olivia Rodrigo to a memoirist whose long-held ballet aspirations stalled at the barre, young women gave voice to their longing this year in memorable ways.
content: When she was just 14, Priscilla Beaulieu, an Air Force brat stationed with her family in Germany, met one of the planet’s biggest pop stars. The pair formed a connection, and when it was time to temporarily part ways, he left her with a keepsake.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By New York Times Games
title: Today’s Wordle Review
description: In case you need some puzzle help.
content: Welcome to The Wordle Review. Be warned: This page contains spoilers for today’s puzzle. Solve Wordle first, or scroll at your own risk.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Anna Kodé
title: From the Lens of Lee Friedlander, Real Estate Focusing on the Real
description: The photographer traveled around the country, shooting the communities we live in, unvarnished and unfiltered.
content: These days, real estate imagery is often defined by staged hotel-lobby-style furniture and generic artwork, dramatic drone shots on unsettlingly perfect sunny days and a lack of human presence — almost never do you see any people or evidence that these homes have been lived in.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jeffery C. Mays and Olivia Bensimon
title: Adams’s Effort to Control Migrant Buses Faces Instant Obstacles
description: A move by Mayor Eric Adams meant to slow the surge of new arrivals being sent to New York from Texas encounters logistical hurdles within 24 hours.
content: A chartered bus from Texas filled with migrants pulled onto a street near the Port Authority Bus Terminal in Midtown Manhattan at 10:03 p.m. Thursday.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Lora Kelley
title: Wanted: ‘New Collar’ Workers
description: The jobs require advanced skills but not necessarily advanced degrees, especially in emerging high-tech fields like A.I., electric vehicles and robotics.
content: Step aside, blue collar. And white collar, pink collar and green collar.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Livia Albeck-Ripka
title: Colorado Springs Police Search for Mother in Death of Two Children
description: Kimberlee Singler, 35, was found injured at an apartment last week with the bodies of two of her children, 9 and 7, the police said. Her 11-year-old daughter was also found injured, they said.
content: The police are searching for a 35-year-old woman charged with murdering two of her children, ages 9 and 7, and injuring a third, age 11, at an apartment in Colorado Springs, Colo., last week, the authorities said Thursday.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jenna Russell, Ernesto Londoño and Shawn Hubler
title: Maine Joins Colorado in Finding Trump Ineligible for Primary Ballot
description: Maine found Donald Trump ineligible to hold office because of his actions after the 2020 election. California said his name would remain on the ballot there.
content: Maine on Thursday became the second state to bar Donald J. Trump from its primary election ballot after its top election official ruled that the former president’s efforts to remain in power after the 2020 election rendered him ineligible to hold office again.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jason Bailey
title: Stream These 9 Movies Before They Leave Netflix in January
description: A lot of big movies by big-name directors are leaving soon for U.S. subscribers. Watch them while you can.
content: In January, several big movies from an impressive coterie of marquee directors — including Sofia Coppola, Luca Guadagnino, Yorgos Lanthimos, Spike Lee, Jordan Peele and Robert Rodriguez — leave Netflix in the United States, along with a zippy comedy, an entertaining animated sequel and what may be the most famous runner-up in Oscars history. (Dates indicate the final day a title is available.)
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Raja Abdulrahim
title: U.N. Says Israeli Forces Fired on Aid Convoy in Central Gaza
description: The convoy, whose vehicles were marked with U.N. insignia, was returning from delivering aid, including flour. No one was injured.
content: Israeli forces shot at a United Nations convoy of armored vehicles in central Gaza on Thursday evening as it was returning from delivering aid in the northern part of the territory, U.N. officials said.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Caitlin Lovinger
title: Variety: Acrostic
description: David Balton and Jane Stewart’s puzzle almost makes you give up before you even start, but you can do it.
content: ACROSTIC — Today’s passage, by that paragon of American satire, Mark Twain, originally appeared in The Territorial Enterprise, a newspaper in Virginia City, Nev., on Jan. 1, 1863. There’s a reason modern funny people receive a prize with his name; Twain’s gift for skewering any subject without losing his charm was magic and still “kills” after 160 years. The excerpt is about humanity’s unfailing annual efforts to overcome vice and embrace virtue, and how quickly they, well, fail. (Twain gives them a life span of about a month.)
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Mitch Smith
title: Judge Blocks Iowa’s Ban on School Library Books That Depict Sex Acts
description: Authors and activists said the Republican-backed law infringed on free speech. The judge said the ban imposed a “puritanical ‘pall of orthodoxy’ over school libraries.”
content: A federal judge in Iowa temporarily blocked on Friday the enforcement of a law backed by Republicans that banned books describing sex acts from public school libraries.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Mia Leimkuhler
title: A New Year Mochi Soup That’s Flexible and Festive
description: Ozoni, full of vegetables and soft orbs of mochi in a soothing broth, is a wonderful way to greet the new year.
content: Hello! Mia here, filling in for Sam, who returns on Sunday. To channel a bit of his sageness, I hope you’ve found little moments of rest and relief this week — this hurtle to the end of the year can be a lot.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Matthew Cullen
title: Russia Launched a Large and Complex Air Attack on Ukraine
description: Also, Ohio’s governor blocked a ban on transition care for minors. Here’s the latest at the end of Friday.
content: Russian forces fired more than 150 missiles and drones into cities across Ukraine today, hitting factories, hospitals and schools in what Ukrainian officials said was the largest air assault since they began tracking them last year.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By The New York Times
title: The Weekender
description: The Chinese spy agency that’s rising to challenge the C.I.A. Also: a look at Donald Trump’s 2025 trade agenda and some thoughts on how to approach Dry January if you’re taking part.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Danielle Dowling
title: 5 Things to Do This Weekend
description: A selection of entertainment highlights this weekend, including Randy Rainbow's concert at the Beacon Theater in Manhattan.
content: A selection of entertainment highlights this weekend, including Randy Rainbow's concert at the Beacon Theater in Manhattan.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Anton Troianovski, Yuliya Parshina-Kottas, Oleg Matsnev, Alina Lobzina, Valerie Hopkins and Aaron Krolik
title: How the Russian Government Silences Wartime Dissent
description: A law making it illegal to discredit Russia’s army has ensnared thousands of Russians for even mild acts or statements against the war.
content: A law making it illegal to discredit Russia’s army has ensnared thousands of Russians for even mild acts or statements against the war.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Michael Roston
title: 6 Great Space Images in December
description: A new view of Uranus, a cat video from space and other scenes from around the solar system in December.
content: A new view of Uranus, a cat video from space and other scenes from around the solar system in December.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Roni Caryn Rabin
title: How Bias Endangers Pregnant Black Women
description: Unconscious bias in the medical profession may be raising risks for pregnant Black women.
content: Unconscious bias in the medical profession may be raising risks for pregnant Black women.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Patrick Healy and Frank Luntz
title: Here’s What 13 Biden and Trump Voters Agreed On About 2023
description: For starters, we heard something unexpected from both Democrats and Republicans about the economy.
content: For starters, we heard something unexpected from both Democrats and Republicans about the economy.
source.name: The New York Times

title: Wanted: ‘New Collar’ Workers
description: The jobs require advanced skills but not necessarily advanced degrees, especially in emerging high-tech fields like A.I., electric vehicles and robotics.
content: The jobs require advanced skills but not necessarily advanced degrees, especially in emerging high-tech fields like A.I., electric vehicles and robotics.
source.name: The New York Times

title: The New York Times News Quiz, Dec. 29, 2023
description: Did you follow the news this week? Take our quiz to see how well you stack up with other Times readers.
content: Did you follow the news this week? Take our quiz to see how well you stack up with other Times readers.
source.name: The New York Times

title: The People Who Lived the Headlines of 2023
description: From wildfires to wars, labor strikes to political protests, 2023 was a big year. All year long, we photographed the people whose lives were shaped by the news.
content: From wildfires to wars, labor strikes to political protests, 2023 was a big year. All year long, we photographed the people whose lives were shaped by the news.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Coral Davenport
title: Strawberry Case Study: What if Farmers Had to Pay for Water?
description: With aquifers nationwide in dangerous decline, one part of California has tried essentially taxing groundwater. New research shows it’s working.
content: With aquifers nationwide in dangerous decline, one part of California has tried essentially taxing groundwater. New research shows it’s working.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Marie Solis
title: The Big Number: $148 Billion
description: Retailers struggle to reduce returns. But the National Retail Federation says more than 15 percent of holiday merchandise will be returned.
content: Retailers struggle to reduce returns. But the National Retail Federation says more than 15 percent of holiday merchandise will be returned.
source.name: The New York Times

title: Two Tiny Cabins on a Washington Island
description: For years, the antique cottage off the coast of Washington had served her well. But with grandchildren on the way, she needed a little extra space.
content: For years, the antique cottage off the coast of Washington had served her well. But with grandchildren on the way, she needed a little extra space.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By The New York Times
title: Russia Launches Widespread Air Attack on Ukrainian Cities
description: Ukrainian officials said more than two dozen people were killed in missile and drone attacks across the country over several hours.
content: Ukrainian officials said more than two dozen people were killed in missile and drone attacks across the country over several hours.
source.name: The New York Times
